DF3C89C1EFE84153B6DFAD0010C00D06.description: Analyze the composition of a chemical sample by using gas chromatography.

0B0BF0C5B7B24CB7AB7F2071EF699CBA.description:
Represent neutralization reactions and reactions between common acids and metals
by using chemical equations.

97D9A74FF780443BA8E71E2294E082A3.description:
Use the calculated molality of a solution to calculate the freezing point depression
and the boiling point elevation of a solution.

68F81DA88F034E0FBB213705AC3C0282.description:
Use solubility rules to write net ionic equations for precipitation reactions in
aqueous solution.

4257915963194206B1146865DD46DE7B.description:
Use a variety of procedures for separating mixtures (including distillation,
crystallization filtration, paper chromatography, and centrifuge).

87E93F38B1A94A49891890F53988C0C1.description: Interpret solubility curves to determine saturation at different temperatures.

792C7AFFC79C474D9A9005D344C95AEA.description:
Explain how the use of a titration can determine the concentration of acid and base
solutions.

E4F0B066C1E94CD88A659F243400EF5D.description:
Use the hydronium or hydroxide ion concentration to determine the pH and pOH of
aqueous solutions.

07064934269642BB8B9E04E658746D22.description: Represent common acids and bases by their names and formulas.

B33F06CA9F76459BBDE28FBA22B37C28.description: Distinguish between strong and weak common acids and bases.

045973FE51854D42BDCEB381F50B0E78.description: Summarize the properties of salts, acids, and bases.

B4EDBE6439E54D43B72A3BEEAD10D60A.description:
Carry out calculations to find the concentration of solutions in terms of molarity and
percent weight (mass).

B53377284829447DB4478F1128DB49A0.description:
Illustrate the colligative properties of solutions (including freezing point depression
and boiling point elevation and their practical uses).

C5D6CD02A0F64192A4B4DB6D9E80C274.description:
Compare solubility of various substances in different solvents (including polar and
nonpolar solvents and organic and inorganic substances).

BAB4E73A2CBB4036B54F1E05FD127F93.description:
Summarize the process by which solutes dissolve in solvents, the dynamic
equilibrium that occurs in saturated solutions, and the effects of varying pressure
and temperature on solubility.

B289CBD0396446C092EDD074BCC24A69.description:
The student will demonstrate an understanding of the nature and properties of
various types of chemical solutions.

8A87DE2D101F49E8909EE636B41E60F2.description:
Analyze a chemical process to account for the weight of all reagents and solvents by
following the appropriate material balance procedures.

0E2EC41292A54386AC1CA9CDE599AA83.description: Analyze a product for purity by following the appropriate assay procedures.

B9050DA5B2384BE79D77906171F46B1B.description: Apply the ideal gas law (pV = nRT) to solve problems.

DB9BFE1F4F61445FB98D9D894E07B668.description:
Use density to determine the mass, volume, or number of particles of a gas in a
chemical reaction.

74F302BEDE7744E289570E5AD94A30A2.description:
Analyze the energy changes involved in calorimetry by using the law of
conservation of energy as it applies to temperature, heat, and phase changes
(including the use of the formulas q = mcΔT [temperature change] and q = mLv and
q = mLf [phase change] to solve calorimetry problems).

BB97C26DD2524E4687097DDA5C4834E5.description:
Illustrate and interpret heating and cooling curves (including how boiling and
melting points can be identified and how boiling points vary with changes in
pressure).

ACFCAC9CB55C4C7DB61CBFE8FA8CB22E.description:
Apply the gas laws to problems concerning changes in pressure, volume, or
temperature (including Charles’s law, Boyle’s law, and the combined gas law).

198FD0A42A71426AA133A6303B4FE70B.description:
Explain the behaviors of gas; the relationship among pressure, volume, and
temperature; and the significance of the Kelvin (absolute temperature) scale, using
the kinetic-molecular theory as a model.

9C0DFA26B004442C917F7C151E9C9194.description: Explain the effects of the intermolecular forces on the different phases of matter.

16D744DFD0BE4BBFBE70B11E0669F099.description:
The student will demonstrate an understanding of the structure and behavior
of the different phases of matter.

45CAAA00452740E58C36C6E8DE883CBA.description:
Explain the role of collision frequency, the energy of collisions, and the orientation
of molecules in reaction rates.

FB5993CC1DD04429933C5F59CFD04422.description: Summarize the concept of chemical equilibrium and Le Châtelier’s principle.

150C6E9D9B6644E692000DC394F7B0F0.description:
Illustrate the uses of electrochemistry (including electrolytic cells, voltaic cells, and
the production of metals from ore by electrolysis).

DB337BD677A241658B6DA96B44D21533.description:
Summarize the oxidation and reduction processes (including oxidizing and reducing
agents).

8D075FB5750C49AC89F4821952A1DAA4.description:
Explain the role of activation energy and the effects of temperature, particle size,
stirring, concentration, and catalysts in reaction rates.

8636C5AAD451496C842859A48B9214EF.description:
Predict the percent yield, the mass of excess, and the limiting reagent in chemical
reactions.

52D437D478CF42DDAC1B538A428563A6.description:
Apply the concept of moles to determine the number of particles of a substance in a
chemical reaction, the percent composition of a representative compound, the mass
proportions, and the mole-mass relationships.

E6CC98BF08634C36822725CA46E95C03.description:
Analyze the energy changes (endothermic or exothermic) associated with chemical
reactions.

0A9869D524CA4054B3CDD68413F43E66.description: Predict the products of acid-base neutralization and combustion reactions.

DD1EAA9F6F484A12837004792FF681A7.description:
Analyze and balance equations for simple synthesis, decomposition, single
replacement, double replacement, and combustion reactions.

10765E857D544E6CAAFEFF69234008DB.description:
The student will demonstrate an understanding of the types, the causes, and
the effects of chemical reactions.

A688DA763BE9409986A5A41DD0BD13E7.description: Classify organic reactions as addition, elimination, or condensation.

9DF3B2410BE148269E1E5346F7DF0BA1.description: Classify polymerization reactions as addition or condensation.

039EC989756F443EBBA9D9A4111C045B.description:
Explain the effect of electronegativity and ionization energy on the type of bonding
in a molecule.

BF6C08D1B0F04DAEB021B3328B504091.description: Classify organic compounds in terms of their functional group.

67C187CE702A464A946F6F1C5D81E95A.description:
Identify the basic structure of common polymers (including proteins, nucleic acids,
plastics, and starches).

09133DCA25534E2CA25040B66D4FABC8.description:
Illustrate the structural formulas and names of simple hydrocarbons
(including alkanes and their isomers and benzene rings).

F1D41EE5E19E40B9A5C481F3709752B0.description:
Explain the unique bonding characteristics of carbon that have resulted in the
formation of a large variety of organic structures.

E46B0100864E4F8A84ECCEA7E581CF55.description:
Explain how the types of intermolecular forces present in a compound affect the
physical properties of compounds (including polarity and molecular shape).

F7D5BC9100E044B0BD177CD09756142D.description: Interpret the names and formulas for ionic and covalent compounds.

8F2CDCC1C3A34E58ADBF00701A643E53.description:
Predict the type of bonding (ionic or covalent) and the shape of simple compounds
by using Lewis dot structures and oxidation numbers.

AA9D4390D1854522825FB16747A40AF4.description:
The student will demonstrate an understanding of the structures and
classifications of chemical compounds.

71CA4CAD0D874D3681A66F157D2CE846.description:
Use the equation E = mc2 to determine the amount of energy released during nuclear
reactions.

9A42FC8B19EB4487A7D9D3DB5DCD7FB1.description:
Analyze a decay series chart to determine the products of successive nuclear
reactions and write nuclear equations for disintegration of specified nuclides.

35F6A4AAEC154DDD8ACAA459C765ED9A.description:
Apply the predictable rate of nuclear decay (half-life) to determine the age of
materials.

B9C4D1780955490AB5AFE1C6F2EF9EA7.description:
Explain the concept of half-life, its use in determining the age of materials, and its
significance to nuclear waste disposal.

5AE9D9EB6D9E42628ABBDD16BF07DBB2.description:
Compare alpha, beta, and gamma radiation in terms of mass, charge, penetrating
power, and the release of these particles from the nucleus.

E157117A02F44B0B88A33B041E3B259C.description:
Compare the nuclear reactions of fission and fusion to chemical reactions (including
the parts of the atom involved and the relative amounts of energy released).

60DDBFBB4F8A44B9843A835B107D94E0.description:
Summarize the periodic table’s property trends (including electron configuration,
ionization energy, electron affinity, atomic size, ionic size, and reactivity).

452ADD55E19D4D8DA98CC3892C3F68CD.description:
Summarize atomic properties (including electron configuration, ionization energy,
electron affinity, atomic size, and ionic size).

76C09C1911C840578AF7BAEF2B3869D5.description:
Illustrate electron configurations by using orbital notation for representative
elements.

4C1BA8E870B84D47A973C8087D6DE6F1.description:
Students will demonstrate an understanding of atomic structure and nuclear
processes.

524BF41589F14829ABBF5BE218287073.description: Use appropriate safety procedures when conducting investigations.

0E4CBA66FD79402990E0C948B6BF6C93.description: Evaluate a technological design or product on the basis of designated criteria.

24881C36F4874886B3AE60AF8FFF9AD2.description:
Evaluate the results of a scientific investigation in terms of whether they verify or
refute the hypothesis and what the possible sources of error are.

D107C76FAB9C427BAF33DBE74E846FDC.description:
Organize and interpret the data from a controlled scientific investigation by using
mathematics (including formulas, scientific notation, and dimensional analysis),
graphs, models, and/or technology.

AD6A2E412943498888D9FDD6AE58030C.description:
Design a scientific investigation with appropriate methods of control to test a
hypothesis (including independent and dependent variables), and evaluate the
designs of sample investigations.

B48DD13B3EE04E8CBE078162DC6CC880.description:
Use scientific instruments to record measurement data in appropriate metric units
that reflect the precision and accuracy of each particular instrument.

CD8B12FDFB16408B8F6A481BA747A4FA.description:
Use appropriate laboratory apparatuses, technology, and techniques safely and
accurately when conducting a scientific investigation.

BD0A504C0BA643258FF1B48A3B38ACE4.description:
Apply established rules for significant digits, both in reading a scientific instrument
and in calculating a derived quantity from measurement.

DF8B75FE39F8414BBD54F36179CDAC01.description:
The student will demonstrate an understanding of how scientific inquiry and
technological design, including mathematical analysis, can be used
appropriately to pose questions, seek answers, and develop solutions.
